qas.question: What was the first botanical garden at an Italian university?
What science was botany considered to be a part of?
Where was the first European botany garden at a university?

context: In the mid-16th century, "botanical gardens" were founded in a number of Italian universities – the <a0_0>Padua<a0_0/> botanical garden in 1545 is usually considered to be the first which is still in <a1_0>its original location<a1_0/>. These gardens continued the practical value of earlier "physic gardens", often associated with monasteries, in which plants were cultivated <a2_0>for medical use<a2_0/>. They supported the growth of botany as an academic subject. Lectures were given about the plants grown in the gardens and their medical uses demonstrated. Botanical gardens came much later to northern Europe; the first in England was the <a4_0>University of Oxford<a4_0/> Botanic Garden in 1621. Throughout this period, botany remained firmly subordinate to <a3_0>medicine<a3_0/>.
